The '''Southern Asia-Pacific Division of Seventh-day Adventists''' is the administrative body for the [[Seventh-day Adventist Church]] in [[Southeast Asia]]. It reported just over 6000 churches and 930,000 people, as of 2009.<ref>http://www.adventistdirectory.org/view_AdmField.asp?AdmFieldID=SSD</ref>
It includes the countries of [[Bangladesh]], [[Brunei|Brunei Darussalam]], [[Cambodia]], [[Federated States of Micronesia]], [[Guam]] & [[Wake Island]], [[Indonesia]], [[Laos]], the [[Marshall Islands]], [[Malaysia]], [[Burma]] (Myanmar), the [[Northern Mariana Islands]], [[Palau]], the [[Philippines]], [[Singapore]], [[Sri Lanka]], [[Thailand]], [[East Timor]] (Timor-Leste), and [[Vietnam]].
It is divided into eight Unions (see: [[government of the Seventh-day Adventist Church]]).
== Malaysia == See also [[Seventh-day Adventist Telugu work: Malaysia|the work amongst]] the [[Telugu people]] in Malaysia.
== Cambodia == The Adventist church is growing in [[Cambodia]].
[[Jombok Hoas]] is a non-profit adventure [[retreat (spiritual)|retreat]] run by the [[Adventist Development and Relief Agency]] (ADRA) in the forest near [[Rovieng]] in [[Preah Vihear Province]].
[[Wat Preah Yesu]] is a children's [[orphanage]], school and church located outside [[Siem Reap]], run by members of the Adventist church.
== Laos == Adventists are one of the three main [[Christianity in Laos|Christian groups in Laos]]. As of 2008 there was one church and 1,740 Adventists in [[Laos]].<ref>http://www.adventistdirectory.org/view_AdmField.asp?EntityID=13090</ref>
